clinical_study.brief_title: Prevalence of Onychodystrophy in Patients With Chronic Venous Disease of the Lower Limbs
clinical_study.official_title: Prevalence of Onychodystrophy in Patients With Chronic Venous Disease of the Lower Limbs

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of the present study is to determine the degree of correlation between clinical severity of chronic venous insufficiency and prevalence of onychodystrophy. The achievement of the study will require previously a synthetic exposition of the two diseases, emphasizing those factors affecting the proposed analysis.

detailed_description.textblock:
The final goal of this work is to determine if patients with increased clinical severity of chronic venous insufficiency have also a higher prevalence of onychodystrophy.
Chronic Venous Insufficiency (CVI) is a vascular disease that responds to a number of different clinical syndromes and is manifested in the lower extremity, whose nexus is venous hypertension (HTV).
Onychodystrophy on the feet is a progressive non-infectious condition associated with various factors, which increases with age. Predominantly occurs in females, presents poor aesthetic appearance and often annoyed with footwear.
The work that is intended to perform is observational, descriptive, analytical, cross-sectional and unicentric. In order to prove the feasibility, the researcher will conduct a previous pilot study. The study will undertake a preliminary investigation work (pilot study) to be performed with a total of 40 patients (aged 40 to 85) who are attending the service of Angiology and Vascular Surgery of the Hospital de Sant Pau. These patients will be selected to verify their data and then the researchers will perform a statistical study from a descriptive and inferential point of view.

primary_outcome.description: An inspection of the nails of the feet will be held to all patients. All the onychodystrophies (main variable of the study) will be described and compared according to what are considered normal nail parameters.

primary_outcome.measure: Prevalence of onychodystrophy in Patients with CVD (chronic venous disease)
primary_outcome.description: Taking into account the variables and applying the criteria of exclusion and inclusion on the studied sample population composed of men and women, and considering if the limb is affected of chronic venous disease, the investigators have observed and come to the conclusion that in the main hypothesis "patients presenting greater scale of chronic venous insufficiency have higher prevalence of onychodystrophy" and the secondary hypothesis "With a greater degree of venous insufficiency, more affected fingers of onychodystrophy", the investigators found that the proportion of patients with chronic venous disease and at the same time presence of onicodistrophy on their feet is very low and a high number of patients do not present that condition on their nails

secondary_outcome.measure: Prevalence of onychodystrophy, in patients with CVD
secondary_outcome.description: In terms of the hypothesis "a large number of the studied patients will have more than one dystrophic finger," the investigators have not been able to extract significant statistical conclusions in the absence of an outcome sufficient and representative . In relation to the hypothesis "the prevalence of the onychodystrophy will be higher in women than in men," we have observed that OD presence is given greater among women, but also it must be said that the number of female patients studied has been higher than that of male patients

other_outcome.measure: Prevalence of onychodystrophy, in patients with CVD other variables of the study
other_outcome.description: In what refers to the hypothesis "the prevalence of the onichodystrophy increase with age in the studied group", the investigators can't extract meaningful conclusions due to the small number of cases studied and that the number of patients found within the fringes of age is very uneven. In general, and grouping patients by strips of age of five in five years, we can see that most of the patients enrolled are between 40 and 45 years old, 60 and 64, and the 70 and 74. However, with the data obtained we can guess the trend that with older age increases the presence of onychodystrophy. About the hypothesis "The main affected nails will be in the first and fifth toes of the limbs ", we have been able to deduce among the subjects studied (both male and female), that onychodystrophy occurs mainly in the first and fifth toe .

intervention.description: collecting data from patients of the Service of Angiology Hospital Sant Pau

study_pop.textblock:
After collecting data, the investigators will establish the variables, among them the results of all clinical data and the scanning Doppler data and CVI symptoms as well as the classification CEAP ( from 0 to 6) specifying to what corresponds according to the condition of every subject, all these data will be analyzed in relation to the presence and intensity of OD in each patient. Also, other variables will be registered that can be related to OD: type of footwear, feet deformation, personal history (medical, dermatological and medications).
Finally, the investigators will perform the statistical analysis putting in relation all the variables to finally determine if there is or not a correlation between CVI and OD

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects with an age range between 40 and 85 years.
- Patients who attend the service of Angiology, Vascular Surgery and Endovascular with chronic venous disease or chronic venous insufficiency in lower extremity and presenting a clinical degree among C0 to C6 scale of the classification CEAP (Clinic-Etiology - Anatomy-Pathophysiology) while at the same time they manifest venous reflux, when exposed to the echo-Doppler scan.
- Patients agreeing to voluntarily participate in the study and that sign the informed consent document.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Congenital Onychopathy
- Presence in any nail plate of fungal, viral or bacterial infections
- Emergence of digital foot deformities
- Manifestation of biomechanical problems
- Presence of degenerative joint disease (arthrosis, arthritis)
- Patients who make or have made routine use of inappropriate or poorly adjusted footwear and especially, those who have onychodystrophy attributable clearly, and directly to the footwear
- Individuals presenting a Greek foot and especially, those that manifest this onychodystrophy in the second toe.
- Patients in which onychodystrophy is due to surgical iatrogenic event
- Individuals presenting subungual tumours (exostosis, tumor Glomus, chondroma, whitlow melanic).
- Patients who take or have taken any drug that is directly associated with a cause of onychodystrophy
- Patients with a history of skin diseases such as psoriasis, Lichen Planus or alopecia areata, that are associated in general with nail manifestations.
- Patients with a background of physical or chemical trauma on the nails of the feet that have clearly given rise to onychodystrophy.
- Individuals, who have any type of amputation of the lower limbs.
- Patients with a history of nail foot surgery (less than a year) or showing any digital amputation (total or partial).
- Individuals that, despite complying with all the requirements of the study, decline to participate or refuse to sign the informed consent document.
- People with any medical illness or psychiatric disorder which, in the opinion of the investigator, preclude them from understand the reason for the selection or were unable to give informed consent to participate in the study
- Subjects with post-thrombotic syndrome.
- The affected lower limb with varicose veins that has undergone surgery with any invasive procedure will be excluded.
- Patients presenting prosthesis or nail cosmetics are also excluded of the study
